timeline.bodyText:
instead of reading data here, another possibility is to create one combined split that contains all the original splits, and have the record reader iterate through the splits later.
Seems like it would be better, since the data is only read once, and protects against weird behavior in certain types of input formats (for example, if there's a pubsub source where the message is acked in the reader).
timeline.author: albertshau

replies.bodyText: hum.. we could and move this logic to the new reader.

timeline.bodyText: since InputSplit is writable, can this just delegate to the split? Or do we need the classname and to use Serializer for some other reason?
timeline.author: albertshau

replies.bodyText: nevermind, was looking at mapred.InputSplit. Don't know why they didn't make it part of the InputSplit contract, seems like it would always be needed...
replies.author: albertshau

timeline.bodyText: Though the current behavior is a limit per split, don't we actually want the limit to be applied overall?
timeline.author: albertshau

replies.bodyText: We calculate limit per split from the overall limit. And in the nextKeyValue() method, the overall limit is enforced there.
replies.author: chtyim

replies.bodyText: Also there is always only one LimitingInputSplit. That's why the read count can be tracked locally.
